story: One day, Alexander and Sam went to the park. It was a cold morning, and the wind blew hard. Alexander found a striped scarf on a bench. It was red and white. He picked it up and looked around, but no one was there. "Sam, look what I found!" Alexander said. Sam was busy kicking a ball and did not hear him. Alexander decided to keep the scarf to stay warm. He wrapped it around his neck and felt cozy. Sam stopped playing and ran over. "Where did you get that scarf?" Sam asked. Alexander told him about finding it on the bench. Sam shrugged and said, "Cool! Let's go get hot chocolate." They walked to a nearby shop, happy and warm. The scarf made Alexander smile. He was glad he found it. The two friends enjoyed their day together, sipping hot drinks and laughing. The end.

The answer depends on how you look at this. To the observer looking in from the outside of their eyelids, it is clear as day.  The question is a rhetorical one, but for those that do not care to look out they way to see their eyes move, perhaps the only thing in front of your pupils was an hourglass. As they are about to turn away with the clock moving along before their very own eyes, you can imagine that such an observer has two options before them. The first one would be something along these lines; I must admit, in this case you were looking up, and from inside my eye's, the pattern was a bright light. At first glance there was an image of what is to come later. Your gaze was upon this picture with your eyelids covering the opening towards our visual system when you first opened it with your eyes as wide open as you could before they shut themselves. To take that route, though one way might have been preferable to the other, but since most people don't consider which option they'd go with at a red traffic light approaching from behind there'll likely always be some sort of obstacle in front of us all unless someone finds a loophole.
